messages.content:
You are a professional academic reference prediction expert. Your task is to predict the most likely references for a given academic paper based on its title, abstract, and retrieved relevant papers.

RETRIEVER INTERFACE:
- Input: paper title + abstract
- Output: {top_r} retrieved papers with title and abstract
- Format: List of dictionaries with 'title' and 'abstract' fields

REQUIREMENTS:
1. Analyze the paper's title and abstract to understand its research area and focus
2. Consider the retrieved papers as potential references (when available)
3. Generate a list of predicted reference titles that would be most relevant and likely to be cited
4. Provide reasoning for each prediction to prevent hallucination
5. Output format: JSON object with "titles" array and "reasoning" string
6. Generate exactly 48 most relevant reference titles (this should be at least 40 to cover all evaluation metrics)
7. Ensure titles are realistic and appropriate for the research area
8. Consider citation patterns in the field
9. CRITICAL: Each title must be unique - never repeat the same title multiple times

EXAMPLE:
Input:
Title: "Question Type Classification Methods Comparison"
Abstract: "The paper presents a comparative study of state-of-the-art approaches for question classification task: Logistic Regression, Convolutional Neural Networks (CNN), Long Short-Term Memory Network (LSTM) and Quasi-Recurrent Neural Networks (QRNN). All models use pre-trained GLoVe word embeddings and trained on human-labeled data. The best accuracy is achieved using CNN model with five convolutional layers and various kernel sizes stacked in parallel, followed by one fully connected layer. The model reached 90.7% accuracy on TREC 10 test set."

Retrieved papers ({top_r}):
1. Title: Convolutional Neural Networks for Sentence Classification
   Abstract: We report on a series of experiments with convolutional neural networks trained on top of pre-trained word vectors for sentence-level classification tasks.

2. Title: Glove: Global vectors for word representation
   Abstract: We present a new global log-bilinear regression model that combines the advantages of the two major model families in the literature.

Output:
{
  "titles": [
    "Convolutional Neural Networks for Sentence Classification",
    "Glove: Global vectors for word representation",
    "Quasi-Recurrent Neural Networks",
    "A Comparative Study of Neural Network Models for Sentence Classification",
    "Deep lstm based feature mapping for query classification"
  ],
  "reasoning": "Based on the paper's focus on question classification using neural networks, I predict these references because: 1) CNN paper is directly relevant to the convolutional approach used; 2) GloVe embeddings are mentioned as pre-trained features; 3) QRNN is one of the compared methods; 4) Comparative study papers are common in this field; 5) LSTM-based query classification is closely related to question classification. Additional references cover related neural network architectures, NLP applications, deep learning methodologies, optimization techniques, and advanced neural network methods that would be relevant for this research area."
}

Return JSON object only.

Paper Title: The Complexity of Diameter on ùêª-free graphs

Paper Abstract: Abstract The intensively studied Diameter problem is to find the diameter of a given connected graph. We investigate, for the first time in a structured manner, the complexity of Diameter for HùêªH-free graphs, that is, graphs that do not contain a fixed graph HùêªH as an induced subgraph. We first show that if HùêªH is not a linear forest with small components, then Diameter cannot be solved in subquadratic time for HùêªH-free graphs under SETH. For some small linear forests, we do show linear-time algorithms for solving Diameter. For other linear forests HùêªH, we make progress towards linear-time algorithms by considering specific diameter values. If HùêªH is a linear forest, the maximum value of the diameter of any graph in a connected HùêªH-free graph class is some constant dmaxsubscriptùëëd_{\max} dependent only on HùêªH. We give linear-time algorithms for deciding if a connected HùêªH-free graph has diameter dmaxsubscriptùëëd_{\max}, for several linear forests HùêªH. In contrast, for one such linear forest HùêªH, Diameter cannot be solved in subquadratic time for HùêªH-free graphs under SETH. Moreover, we even show that, for several other linear forests HùêªH, one cannot decide in subquadratic time if a connected HùêªH-free graph has diameter dmaxsubscriptùëëd_{\max} under SETH.

{retrieved_text}

Generate exactly 48 most likely reference titles for this paper. Focus on papers that are directly related to the research topic, provide foundational background, present similar methodologies, or address related problems.

CRITICAL: Each title must appear exactly once. Do not repeat any title.

IMPORTANT: You must respond with ONLY valid JSON in this exact format:
{
    "titles": [
        "Reference Title 1",
        "Reference Title 2",
        "Reference Title 3",
        "Reference Title 4",
        "Reference Title 48"
    ],
    "reasoning": "Explain why you chose these specific references based on the paper's title, abstract, and retrieved papers. This helps prevent hallucination and ensures relevance."
}

Do not include any text before or after the JSON. Do not include authors, venues, or years - only the paper titles. The reasoning field is required to explain your prediction logic.

{
    "titles": [
        "Subcubic equivalences between graph centrality problems, APSP, and diameter",
        "What else can Voronoi diagrams do for diameter in planar graphs?",
        "More applications of the polynomial method to algorithm design",
        "Approximation and fixed parameter subquadratic algorithms for radius and diameter in sparse graphs",
        "Towards tight approximation bounds for graph diameter and eccentricities",
        "The algorithmic use of hypertree structure and maximum neighbourhood orderings",
        "Multivariate analysis of orthogonal range searching and graph distances",
        "Subquadratic algorithms for the diameter and the sum of pairwise distances in planar graphs",
        "Deterministic APSP, orthogonal vectors, and more: Quickly derandomizing razborov-smolensky",
        "Better approximation algorithms for the graph diameter",
        "Notes on diameters, centers, and approximating trees of delta-hyperbolic geodesic spaces and graphs",
        "Fast approximation of eccentricities and distances in hyperbolic graphs",
        "Diameter determination on restricted graph families",
        "On the power of BFS to determine a graph‚Äôs diameter",
        "Fully polynomial FPT algorithms for some classes of bounded clique-width graphs",
        "Algorithmic applications of baur-strassen‚Äôs theorem: Shortest cycles, diameter, and matchings",
        "Centers of graphs and the helly property",
        "HT-graphs: centers, connected r-domination and steiner trees",
        "Dominating cliques in distance-hereditary graphs",
        "Œ±isubscriptùõºùëñ\\alpha_{i}-metric graphs: Radius, diameter and all eccentricities",
        "Fast deterministic algorithms for computing all eccentricities in (hyperbolic) Helly graphs",
        "Eccentricity function in distance-hereditary graphs",
        "Revisiting radius, diameter, and all eccentricity computation in graphs through certificates",
        "LexBFS-orderings of distance-hereditary graphs with application to the diametral pair problem",
        "Lexbfs-orderings and powers of graphs",
        "Faster matrix multiplication via asymmetric hashing",
        "Beyond Helly graphs: The diameter problem on absolute retracts",
        "The diameter of AT-free graphs",
        "Optimal centrality computations within bounded clique-width graphs",
        "Distance problems within Helly graphs and k-Helly graphs",
        "A story of diameter, radius, and (almost) Helly property",
        "Diameter computation on H-minor free graphs and graphs of bounded (distance) VC-dimension",
        "Tight hardness results for distance and centrality problems in constant degree graphs",
        "Computation of the center and diameter of outerplanar graphs",
        "Voronoi diagrams on planar graphs, and computing the diameter in deterministic o~‚Äã(n5/3)~ùëúsuperscriptùëõ53{\\tilde{o}}(n^{5/3}) time",
        "A synthesis on partition refinement: A useful routine for strings, graphs, boolean matrices and automata",
        "Split graphs",
        "Domination when the stars are out",
        "On the complexity of k-SAT",
        "Which problems have strongly exponential complexity?",
        "Complexity framework for forbidden subgraphs",
        "Paw-fee graphs",
        "A simple linear-time algorithm for computing the center of an interval graph",
        "Fast approximation algorithms for the diameter and radius of sparse graphs",
        "All pairs shortest paths in undirected graphs with integer weights",
        "Approximating the diameter of planar graphs in near linear time",
        "A new algorithm for optimal 2-constraint satisfaction and its implications",
        "All pairs shortest paths using bridging sets and rectangular matrix multiplication"
    ],
    "reasoning": "Selected these 48 references because they represent foundational work and recent advances in The Complexity of Diameter on ùêª-free graphs, providing essential background knowledge and methodological foundations relevant to this research."
}
